snp2.5:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gayāyaṃ viharati ṭaṅkitamañce sūcilomassa yakkhassa bhavane.
snp2.5:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on the cut-stone ledge in the haunt of Spiky the native spirit.

snp2.5:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kharo ca yakkho sūcilomo ca yakkho bhagavato avidūre atikkamanti.
snp2.5:1.3.eng: Now at that time the native spirits Shaggy and Spiky were passing by not far from the Buddha.
snp2.5:1.3.comm: “Shaggy” is khara and “Spiky” is sūciloma, literally “needle-hair”. Some yakkhas are magnificent kings or warriors, but this pair are more like grotesque demons (rakkhasas), a stereotype that bedeviled yakṣas of later times. Khara is found for a number of demons in Sanskrit. We don’t find suciloma, but compare the demons Khara and his twin sister, the ugly and mutilated Śūrpaṇakhā (“wicker-nails”).

snp2.5:1.4.pli: Atha kho kharo yakkho sūcilomaṃ yakkhaṃ etadavoca:

snp2.5:1.7.pli: Yāvāhaṃ jānāmi yadi vā so samaṇo, yadi vā so samaṇako”ti.
snp2.5:1.7.eng: I’ll soon find out whether he’s an ascetic or a faker.”

snp2.5:2.1.pli: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato kāyaṃ upanāmesi.
snp2.5:2.1.eng: Then Spiky went up to the Buddha and leaned up against his body,

snp2.5:2.3.pli: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp2.5:2.3.eng: Then Spiky said to the Buddha,

snp2.5:3.1.eng: “I will ask you a question, ascetic.

snp2.5:3.2.pli: Sace me na byākarissasi, cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmi, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmī”ti.
snp2.5:3.2.eng: If you don’t answer me, I’ll drive you insane, or explode your heart, or grab you by the feet and throw you to the far shore of the Ganges!”
snp2.5:3.2.comm: Considering the Ganges is 100 km away, this is even more impressive.

snp2.5:4.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ taṃ, āvuso, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yo me cittaṃ vā khipeyya hadayaṃ vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipeyya.
snp2.5:4.1.eng: “I don’t see anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans who could do that to me.

snp2.5:4.2.pli: Api ca tvaṃ, āvuso, puccha yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
snp2.5:4.2.eng: But anyway, ask what you wish.”

snp2.5:4.3.pli: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
snp2.5:4.3.eng: Then Spiky addressed the Buddha in verse:

snp2.5:5.1.eng: “Where do greed and hate come from?
snp2.5:5.1.comm: Despite their savage demeanor, they pivot right away to deep Dhamma questions. This kind of rapid pivot is characteristic of such conversion narratives.

snp2.5:5.2.eng: From where spring discontent, desire, and terror?

snp2.5:5.3.eng: Where do the mind’s thoughts originate,

snp2.5:5.4.eng: like a crow let loose by boys.”

snp2.5:6.2.eng: from here spring discontent, desire, and terror;

snp2.5:6.3.eng: here’s where the mind’s thoughts originate,

snp2.5:6.4.eng: like a crow let loose by boys.

snp2.5:7.1.eng: Born of affection, originating in oneself,

snp2.5:7.2.eng: like prop roots sprouting from a banyan;
snp2.5:7.2.comm: The banyan is “trunk-born” (khandhaja) in two ways. As an epiphyte, it is sometimes called the “strangler fig”, since it grows around the trunk of a previous tree, strangling it. Then the banyan sends out aerial roots from the branches; when they reach the ground they establish themselves as supportive trunks known as “prop roots”, so that even if original trunk dies, the tree survives. Thus the tree itself is “trunk-born” and its multiple prop roots are also “trunk-born”. Grammar and commentary indicate the second sense is meant here. The metaphor is even more apt, since the word nigrodha (“banyan”) means “down-grower”, as the tree grows not to the sky but back into the earth.

snp2.5:7.3.eng: the many kinds of attachment to sensual pleasures

snp2.5:7.4.eng: are like camel’s foot creeper <j>creeping through the woods.
snp2.5:7.4.comm: The “camel’s foot creeper” (māluva) takes root and grows over the tree, ultimately engulfing and destroying it (MN 45:4.1).

snp2.5:8.1.eng: Those who understand where they come from

snp2.5:8.2.eng: get rid of them—listen up, spirit!

snp2.5:8.3.eng: They cross this flood so hard to cross,

snp2.5:8.4.eng: not crossed before, so as to not be reborn.”

snp2.6:1.1.eng: A righteous life, a spiritual life,
snp2.6:1.1.comm: The titles Dhammacariyasutta and Kapilasutta are both found in manuscripts and commentary. In the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, Dhammacariyasutta is attested both in the concluding title for the sutta and in the summary verse for this chapter (Snp 2.14:31.3), while Kapilasutta is attested in the summary verse of the sutta Nipāta as a whole (Snp 5.19:22.2; neither BJT nor PTS has any equivalent for this section so it is probably a late Burmese addition). The BJT has Kapilasutta throughout, while PTS has Dhammacariyasutta throughout, acknowledging Kapilasutta only for the commentary. Given that kapila does not occur in the sutta itself, while dhammacariya occurs in the first line, most likely kapila made its way into the title by contamination from the commentary, which tells an extensive story of a bad monk named Kapila, who the Buddha interrogates after he is reborn as a fish. The Vinaya also knows a monk of dubious morals named Kapila Bu Pc 2:7.48.1.

snp2.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
snp2.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

snp2.7:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā kosalakā brāhmaṇamahāsālā jiṇṇā vuḍḍhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
snp2.7:1.3.eng: Then several old and well-to-do brahmins of Kosala—elderly and senior, who were advanced in years and had reached the final stage of life—went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

snp2.7:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te brāhmaṇamahāsālā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
snp2.7:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

snp2.7:1.5.pli: “sandissanti nu kho, bho gotama, etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ brāhmaṇadhamme”ti?
snp2.7:1.5.eng: “Worthy Gotama, are the ancient traditions of the brahmins exhibited these days among brahmins?”

snp2.7:1.6.pli: “Na kho, brāhmaṇā, sandissanti etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ brāhmaṇadhamme”ti.

snp2.7:1.7.pli: “Sādhu no bhavaṃ gotamo porāṇānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ brāhmaṇadhammaṃ bhāsatu, sace bhoto gotamassa agarū”ti.
snp2.7:1.7.eng: “If you wouldn’t mind, worthy Gotama, please teach us the ancient traditions of the brahmins.”

snp2.7:1.8.pli: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇā, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
snp2.7:1.8.eng: “Well then, brahmins, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

snp2.7:1.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho te brāhmaṇamahāsālā bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

snp2.7:7.1.comm: The period of 48 years is also mentioned at AN 5.192:5.4. This is found in Āpastamba Dharmasūtra 1.11.30.2  and Baudhāyana Dharmasūtra 1.2.3.1, both of which belong to the same Yajur Veda tradition as the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa. This is one of several indications that the Buddha was connected with this tradition, probably via his former teachers (see Snp 3.4:7.3, MN 26:15.6, DN 29:16.13). By contrast, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.7.3 mentions 32 years.

snp2.7:20.1.comm: I’m not entirely convinced that ganthetvā means “composed” here. It’s the only early usage in this sense, and the reading is derived from the highly polemical commentary. It may mean just that they “put together” i.e. “selected” favorable passages. This would be less nasty to the brahmins and more historically plausible (as we know that the Vedas are, in fact, old.)

snp2.7:30.1.comm: Bodhi has “by violence”, Norman has “of using violence”, but daṇḍānaṁ is genitive plural. Neither comment on the extreme implausibility of the commentary’s explanation that this is the “three rods” of the body (speech and mind), despite the fact that the Buddha explicitly rejected this term (MN 56:4.3); and anyway, how are acts of speech and mind relevant here? At Rig Veda 7.33.6 we find daṇḍā as “goads” for driving cattle; at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.4.2.5 they are implements at the sacrifice; while ŚB 5.4.4.7 refers to “beating with rods”. Thus it’s likely that here the daṇḍā are the sticks, rods, or goads used on the cows.

snp2.7:30.2.comm: The Buddha did not believe that the antiquity of a custom proved its virtue.

snp2.7:34.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

snp2.8:1.1.eng: If you would learn the teaching from someone,
